title: Target
transcript:
JAMES RONDEAU: The work that Jasper Johns made in the late 1950s and early 1960s really changed the course of American painting.

NARRATOR: Target is one of a series of paintings Jasper Johns made beginning in the 1950s which featured recognizable signs and symbols. They were, as he described them, ‘things the mind already knows.” Director James Rondeau.

JAMES RONDEAU: It was regarded as backward-looking or somehow provincial to be working with representational imagery. Johns is working at a time when a dominant conversation in American painting is abstract, gestural, brushy works of art that are known collectively as abstract expressionism.

NARRATOR: Target pulled away from abstract expressionism.

JAMES RONDEAU: What is a target if it’s not something that defines a center point? And this is in some ways a kind of inside joke that’s, again, contradicting the dominant mode of abstract painting at the time, which was dependent upon the phrase “all over”.

NARRATOR: Contemporaries like Jackson Pollock dripped and flung paint onto the canvas, but Johns worked more methodically with encaustic, paint mixed with molten wax, and layered in bits of newspaper.

And…where abstract expressionist artists sought to put their emotions down on the canvas, Johns chose to use ‘found’ images that seemed impersonal, objective…and conceptual.

JAMES RONDEAU: We look at it and we see that it’s a target, but it also is in some ways abstract. Because what makes a target other than a series of concentric circles, right? There is a pure geometry to this image that if you, say, came from a different culture and didn’t know that this was something we call target, you would actually just see a series of concentric circles.

And then maybe the last idea, which is in a way the most philosophical, is once you have a target, is it an image or is it an object? A target is something that can have no representation of itself; it can only and always be a target.
